etymologies: late 16th century (denoting a mark made by pricking or branding): via Latin from Greek stigma ‘a mark made by a pointed instrument, a dot’; related to stick

definitions: a mark of disgrace associated with a particular circumstance, quality, or person

examples.text: the stigma of having gone to prison will always be with me
debt has lost its stigma and is now a part of everyday life

definitions: (in Christian tradition) marks corresponding to those left on Christ's body by the Crucifixion, said to have been impressed by divine favour on the bodies of St Francis of Assisi and others.
shortDefinitions: (in Christian tradition) marks corresponding to those left on Christ's body by Crucifixion

definitions: a visible sign or characteristic of a disease

examples.text: knee deformities or other stigmata of childhood rickets

shortDefinitions: visible sign or characteristic of disease

definitions: a mark or spot on the skin.
(in a flower) the part of a pistil that receives the pollen during pollination.
shortDefinitions: (in flower) part of pistil that receives pollen during pollination
